skill.name: playwright-skill

skill.summary: Automate browser tasks with Playwright. Write test scripts, take screenshots, test responsive design, and validate web functionality.
skill.author: lackeyjb

security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate Playwright browser automation skill with 293 static findings that are nearly all false positives. The scanner flagged documentation examples in markdown files as code. Actual code review confirms legitimate patterns: npm install for setup, file operations in /tmp, and localhost dev server detection. No credential exfiltration, malicious network calls, or security vulnerabilities detected.

low_findings.title: Static scanner flagged documentation as executable code
low_findings.description: Of 293 static findings, 230+ are from SKILL.md and API_REFERENCE.md. These are bash code examples in markdown showing users how to run the skill. The scanner incorrectly treated documentation as executable code.

low_findings.title: Playwright setup via npm install
low_findings.description: run.js executes npm install and npx playwright install chromium to set up Playwright dependencies. This is standard setup behavior for a browser automation tool and only runs if Playwright is not already installed.

low_findings.title: Localhost dev server detection
low_findings.description: helpers.js makes HEAD requests to common ports (3000, 3001, 8080, etc.) on localhost to detect running development servers. This is a convenience feature with 500ms timeout. No external network access.

low_findings.title: Environment variable access for configuration
low_findings.description: The skill reads HEADLESS, SLOW_MO, PW_HEADER_NAME, PW_HEADER_VALUE for runtime configuration. These control browser visibility and HTTP headers for testing. No sensitive data accessed.

low_findings.title: Temporary file creation in /tmp
low_findings.description: run.js creates temporary execution files in /tmp with pattern .temp-execution-*.js. These are cleaned up on next run. This is safer than writing to the project directory.

content.value_statement: Playwright skill automates web testing with visible browser execution. It detects local dev servers, writes test scripts to temporary storage, and handles form filling, screenshots, and responsive design validation without cluttering your project.
actual_capabilities: Auto-detect running development servers on ports 3000, 3001, 5173, 8080, and other common ports
Write and execute custom Playwright test scripts with visible browser feedback
Capture full-page screenshots and viewport-specific images
Test responsive layouts across desktop, tablet, and mobile viewports
Automate form filling, login flows, and button click sequences
Extract table data, validate page elements, and check for broken links
limitations: Requires Node.js and Playwright installation via npm run setup
Test scripts are temporary and written to /tmp directory only
Headless mode required on systems without graphical display
Cannot test desktop applications or non-web interfaces

use_cases.title: Automated regression testing
use_cases.description: QA engineers automate repetitive test cases by asking the skill to write and execute Playwright scripts. The skill detects dev servers, runs tests with visible browser, and captures screenshots of failures.

use_cases.title: Responsive design validation
use_cases.description: Frontend developers verify layouts across breakpoints by requesting multi-viewport screenshots. The skill tests desktop, tablet, and mobile sizes, reporting layout shifts and visual bugs.

use_cases.title: End-to-end workflow testing
use_cases.description: Full-stack developers test complete user journeys from login to checkout. The skill fills forms, navigates pages, waits for async operations, and validates success states.

output_examples.output: Playwright skill detects server on port 3000, writes test script to /tmp/playwright-test-screenshot.js, launches visible Chromium browser, navigates to page, captures full-page screenshot to /tmp/screenshot.png, and reports completion with file path.

Skill creates test script with three viewport configurations, takes screenshots at each size named desktop.png, tablet.png, mobile.png in /tmp, and summarizes results with file paths and any observed layout shifts.

output_examples.input: Test login with username admin and password test123
output_examples.output: Script fills login form fields, clicks submit button, waits for navigation, verifies current URL contains dashboard, reports login success or failure with screenshot evidence saved to /tmp.

best_practices: Always use detectDevServers helper when testing localhost to find the correct port automatically
Write test scripts to /tmp directory to avoid cluttering your project with temporary automation files
Use visible browser mode for debugging by setting headless false, then switch to headless true for CI pipelines
anti_patterns: Do not hardcode production URLs or real user credentials in test scripts shared publicly
Avoid testing external websites without permission or rate limit awareness
Do not write test files to project directories when /tmp is available and safer

faq.question: What is playwright-skill?
faq.answer: A browser automation skill for Claude Code that uses Playwright to test websites. It writes test scripts to temporary storage and executes them with visible browser feedback for debugging.

faq.question: How do I install Playwright?
faq.answer: Navigate to the skill directory and run npm run setup. This installs Playwright and Chromium browser. Installation is only needed once per system.

faq.question: Can I test production websites?
faq.answer: Yes, but use caution. The skill is designed for localhost development servers. For production testing, ensure you have authorization and respect rate limits.

faq.question: Where are test scripts saved?
faq.answer: All test scripts are written to /tmp/playwright-test-*.js as temporary files. Your operating system automatically cleans these files periodically.

faq.question: How do I enable headless mode?
faq.answer: Set the HEADLESS environment variable to true, or specify headless true in the browser launch options. Default is visible mode for easier debugging.

faq.question: Can I add custom HTTP headers?
faq.answer: Yes. Set PW_HEADER_NAME and PW_HEADER_VALUE environment variables for a single header, or PW_EXTRA_HEADERS as JSON object for multiple headers.
